campaign.story:
Bottom of the 9th, designed by Darrell Louder (designer of Compounded) and Mike Mullins, is a quick dice and card game for 1 or 2 players that encapsulates the thrills and spills of baseball's final inning into a head-to-head competition between an ace pitcher and a star-studded line-up of heavy hitting batters. A game of Bottom of the 9th can easily be played in 5 to 15 minutes.
Bottom of the 9th will feature 20 player cards with beautiful custom art from artist Adam McIver that capture the look of classic baseball trading cards. These cards will even feel like classic trading cards since they will be printed on 1mm punchboard, just like vintage cards.  
Each player card features abilities that can be used when they gain an upper hand on the opponent, allowing them to manipulate dice. Pitchers have an ace pitch that will activate when they choose to throw it as long as the batter doesn't predict both of the pitch variables (High, Low, Inside, Outside).Batters will have a unique MVP ability that activates whenever the player is able to accurately predict the type of pitch thrown. Most players also have a latent trait that can affect the game, alter their play style - or even give an advantage to the opponent!
With myriad customizable line-ups, the possibility of two added expansion packs in the stretch goals, and rules for advanced league and solo play, Bottom of the 9th will keep gamers wanting to play ball time and time again.
Bottom of the 9th will offer the same hallmark replay value as other Dice Hate Me Games titles, with high-quality components, thick punchboard bits, and lots of wood. Here's a list of what you'll find inside the box:
20 punchboard player cards, full-color front and one-color back, in a foil-wrapped pack
2 reference cards
2 playing field pieces in card stock
1 custom silk-screened Pitch Die
1 Pitching Control Die
1 Swing Die 
4 wooden base-runners
4 wooden Pitch Tokens (2 red, 2 white)
3 wooden Out markers
2 wooden Strike markers
3 wooden Ball markers
2 wooden Fatigue markers
Punchboard "stick of gum" batter ball and strike count tracker
15 Event & Scenario mini cards for solo play
Full-color rulebook
Sticker sheet (for Pitch Tokens and Fatigue Markers)
Bottom of the 9th will come in the Dice Hate Me Games "Monkey"-sized box - the same size as The Great Heartland Hauling Co., Belle of the Ball, and Carnival. What's this crazy talk? Take a look here for more information on our box sizes and game categories!
Bottom of the 9th is a distinguished alum of the Unpub program - a series of public and private playtest events held each year to help designers present, hone and polish their game designs with the gaming public, as well as board game production professionals.
How to play Bottom of the 9th, from Rodney Smith of Watch it Played!
Watch a full game of Bottom of the 9th! 
Want to try out Bottom of the 9th for yourself? You can download the print-and-play files right here! You'll need to provide a few components of your own (like some tokens and three dice), but we'll give you the board, the rules, and a sampling of enough pitchers and batters to really get a feel for the game.
For those wanting a video how-to-play, here's a great overview of game play by Steve Tower of After Further Review.
Rodney Smith of Watch It Played is also preparing one of his excellent gameplay videos that should be available later this week. Stay tuned, and we'll post as soon as it's ready!
And for those wanting to know more about the development of the game and a discussion on gameplay, you can listen to designer Darrell Louder talk all about it on Ep. 80 of The State of Games podcast! It's a great episode, all about the Dice Hate Me Games and Greater Than Games merger, but for those just wanting jump straight into the Bottom of the 9th action, that starts at the 1hr 11min mark!
Bottom of the 9th was originally designed as a head-to-head competition between two players - that is, until veteran game designer Richard Launius (Defenders of the Realm; Arkham Horror; Run, Fight or Die)  caught baseball fever after playing the game. 
Richard has been a fan for much of his life - the Chicago White Sox adopted his uniform design for the ball club back in 1981, after all - so when the veteran game designer dropped us a line and said he had an idea for solo play? We were all ears.
The man, the myth, the legend - Richard Launius, ace fielder.
Richard's design concept pits one player, controlling the batting lineup, against a randomly-controlled ace pitcher. Scenario and event cards control the game state, creating managing decisions during the game for the player-controlled team. Mike Mullins has been developing and refining Richard's core concept through tweaks and tests, and we are very excited to offer this solo play option inside the box.
Stay tuned to future updates for a link to the refined solo rules!
Achieving our base funding goal ensures that Dice Hate Me Games will be able to publish Bottom of the 9th with the quality that we all have come to expect. The base game of Bottom of the 9th is priced according to our initial funding goal; however, if we exceed that funding goal we will be able to add more to the game!
Here is a list of potential stretch goals that would allow us to upgrade components and help us add expansion decks to the game!
ACHIEVED! Folding Playing Field game board - One goal we're super excited about, which is why we put it first! We can now upgrade the Playing Field from cardstock to a thick, dual-fold game board!
ACHIEVED! Laser-etched Pitching Die - We can now afford to upgrade the custom Pitch Control Die from silk-screened to laser-etched.
ACHIEVED! Big League Support expansion pack - This stretch goal introduces 12 new player cards to the game in an expansion pack outside the box (some of which you can see above). There'll be some new pitchers and batters, but with this pack we'll also introduce support personnel such as general managers, a trainer, and even mascots. It'll even be foil-wrapped like baseball cards! The retail value of the expansion pack will be $4.95, but each backer will receive the Big League Support pack for free as part of their pledge!
ACHIEVED! Silk-screened Pitching Tokens - We can now do away with the sticker sheet and silk screen the information right onto the wooden Pitching Tokens!
ACHIEVED! Custom Base Runner Meeples - With this stretch goal, the base runners will be wearing little hats and sprinting for the next base!
ACHIEVED! Sentinels of the 9th expansion pack - In case you missed the news, Dice Hate Me Games and Greater Than Games (makers of the awesome Sentinels of the Multiverse line of card games) have merged! That means we can easily combine resources and do crazy things like put superheroes in our baseball games! In this expansion, you'll be able to bring some familiar Multiverse heroes and characters like Legacy, Haka, Tempest and Mr. Chomps to the field. This would be another expansion pack added outside of the box and retailing for $4.95 - but, of course, backers will receive it for free, adding even more value to your pledge!
ACHIEVED! Custom Pitcher Meeple - This stretch goal will be a little meeple for the mound! It serves no in-game purpose, but it's still amazingly cool. This will be a Kickstarter promotional not included in the regular retail version of the game, and will only be initially available as convention or contest promotionals.
Please help spread the word of Bottom of the 9th to family, friends and anyone else you think would enjoy the game so that we can reach our funding goal and roll out those stretch goals!
“Bottom of the 9th is the best baseball simulation I have ever played.” - Mike Fitzgerald, veteran designer of Wyvern, Mystery Rummy, Hooyah, and Baseball Highlights: 2045 (and not to take anything away from Mike's own Baseball Highlights: 2045 which is one of the best baseball games we've ever played)
“Not since APBA have I enjoyed a baseball game as much as Bottom of the 9th. Suspense, strategy, getting into your opponents head, and dice make this a game that is a Must Buy on the Rolling Dice & Taking Names game scale.” - Tony McRee, Rolling Dice & Taking Names podcast 
“Bottom of the 9th is exactly what I wanted it to be - a tense and exciting showdown between pitcher and batter with everything on the line.” - Ben Pinchback, co-designer of Fleet and Eggs & Empires
"I could give you a longer review – yes, but this is a meeple-sized one. And in the end, it really boils down to this – Bottom of the 9th feels like a game that Dice Hate Me Games would put out, not just in its classic Americana theme, but also in its gameplay. Games published by Dice Hate Me seem to have their own rhythm and cadence in their gameplay, and Bottom of the 9th fits that “Dice Hate Me Games feel” to a tee. If you are a fan of baseball or even a fan of games published by Dice Hate Me Games, Bottom of the 9th really should be a game you take a closer look at." - Ryan Sanders, The Inquisitive Meeple 
"Bottom of the 9th is reminiscent of the old, pure, luck-based dice-rolling baseball games. It adds strategy and replayability while retaining enough of a luck mechanic to keep you twitching for your d6 when that pesky batter manages to catch a piece of a pitch and you need to throw him out at first. Quick, fun, and addicting. Best sports game you don't play with a ball." - Brian Gerdwagen
"This game is tons of fun. It offers up the same feeling of tension as you would while playing (or watching) a real game when it is all on the line. Each game you play will tell a different story." - Steebin, The League of Nonsensical Gamers
"Love how much tension was crammed into such a small game. The selection of pitch location and then the die roll really had you on edge. I also really enjoyed the nostalgia you incorporated with the layout/design.” - Dan Halstad, League of Nonsensical Gamers
"Loved this game. Instant backer when it hits Kickstarter!” - Steve Seebode, Unpub designer and playtester
For those true ball fans who want the very best, we're proud to offer a limited amount of ALL-STAR GAME pledge levels. When you pledge for this level, you'll receive one full copy of Bottom of the 9th signed by Darrell and Mike with all applicable stretch goals, as well as a special clipboard field, signed and numbered, complete with several sheets of box score tracking pads to record your games and league play! You'll also receive a limited promotional Blüdle the Noodle mascot card - the official mascot of the Unpub Network! Blüdle was given away as a promotional at Unpub 5 in Baltimore, so only attendees of that convention own an official Blüdle.
These promotional items will only be available for purchase during this Kickstarter campaign. However, you may still be able to find Blüdle through certain convention giveaways, or by using Sentinels Points at the Greater Than Games booth at conventions. The clipboards will be given out as prizes for winners of upcoming Bottom of the 9th tournaments at conventions. So if you don't grab the ALL-STAR GAME pledge level here, keep an eye out for these possible promotions at conventions throughout the year!
And if you still really, really want Blüdle and can't get an ALL-STAR GAME pledge level, you can add on a promotional Blüdle card to any pledge for an additional $5! This card is slightly different than the limited card given out at Unpub 5, but it'll still enable you to easily add Blüdle to your games of Bottom of the 9th!
Without our Kickstarter Backers, Dice Hate Me Games would not be able to bring quality games to market. To show our respect and appreciation, DHMG promises that backer copies of Bottom of the 9th will be shipped out before copies are available for purchase at retailers or conventions. DHMG also pledges to keep all backers informed at every step in the development, printing and delivery processes. We love staying in touch with all of our supporters, so please never hesitate to contact us with questions and concerns.
Greetings ball gamers!
It’s officially spring training time and I am super excited for this Kickstarter campaign! Since we started developing and showing off Bottom of the 9th a year ago, so many board game and baseball fans have been expressing enthusiasm and support for the game. Honestly, I can’t remember a game that we’ve announced that has generated more buzz and excitement than Bottom of the 9th, and that is humbling and amazing!
It’s also an exciting time for Dice Hate Me Games, as we recently announced our merger with Greater Than Games, which you can read all about here and listen to us talk about here. Some of you who have been supporters of Dice Hate Me Games for a few years now have asked if this will change anything about what DHMG is known for or what we love to do. The emphatic answer is absolutely not - this can only make things better! Dice Hate Me Games and Greater Than Games will be able to work together to bring you the absolute best games out there, guaranteed. This is an amazing opportunity for us - and an incredible time to be a fan of both companies!
As always, I appreciate the continued love and support from our Kickstarter family. You’re the absolute best in the game!
Happy ballgaming!
Chris
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
As with any project that involves the production and manufacture of a good to be delivered, there is certainly a real chance for hiccups, delays and more than one or two gremlins gumming up the works along the way. Many boardgame projects on Kickstarter have been seriously hampered by art production delays, problems with an overseas factory, missing units and one shipping snafu after another.

Luckily, we have a few projects under our belt, and have dealt with many of those snafus and gremlins along the way. We have a good working relationship with our overseas manufacturer and have become accustomed to their protocols, communication styles and general idiosyncrasies. We try to plan for all contingencies, and have worked through - and learned from - kinks we may have encountered in our past projects.

We won't lie - stuff happens. Delays can occur. Sometimes you have to go back and forth on color samples six times just to get the color right, and even then the color isn't perfect. Sometimes even personal life events can blindside you. But what we do promise is that we will hold ourselves to the same high standards we expect from other board game publishers, and we will be completely honest and open with each of you every step of the way.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content: Hey, everyone! It's that time of year when thoughts turn to baseball, and we thought that would be a perfect time to launch a Kickstarter for the Clubhouse Expansion to Bottom of the 9th on Kickstarter!

Hello, ball gamers!
We hope you are enjoying the ability to play baseball year-round with Bottom of the 9th. We have been working behind the scenes on the future of the game with a BIG BOX expansion coming out next month that includes new players, equipment, and more! As exciting as all that is though, that is not the reason for this post! 
Bottom of the 9th has been nominated by Board Game Geek as one of the best 2-Player Games of 2015! As much of an honor as that is, how much better would it be if we won it? I say "we" because the game would’ve never happened without your help. So if you have a moment, and a BoardGameGeek.com account, head on over to the nominations page and throw a vote towards Bottom of the 9th in the Best 2-Player category!

updates.update_userinfo: The Gen Con promos have arrived!
updates.update_content:
Apparently all it takes to get the Gen Con promos into our warehouse is for us to start packing and shipping things!
That's right, they've arrived! So all packages that go out now will have everything. Unfortunately, that means there are several that have already been packed that will not have the promos in them. Don't worry, though; like we'd announced before, you'll still be getting them, just in a separate shipment.

Hey, everyone!
The subject of this update really says it all, but the pitch is away! Bottom of the 9th is beginning to leave our warehouse today, and it should be arriving to you very soon. Our goal is to have every copy out by the end of the week.

Greetings ball gamers! 
I see from the recent comments that some of you are getting a bit anxious about the game shipping out, so I thought I'd drop in with a quick update. 
The games have arrived safely at our warehouse and are being sorted, counted and prepped for shipping, which should begin early next week. Most of the team is in Australia working PAX, so Jodie, our warehouse manager, is doing her best to inventory the games and extra bits this week. Darrell is also doing his part by signing 156 games so they'll be ready to roll! By the time things are sorted and ready, the promos should arrive at the same time we're shipping out, so everything will be in the box at the same time.

Hey, everyone! This is just a reminder that the deadline for getting into the main shipment of Bottom of the 9th is tonight at 11:59 PM Central time! As of right now, this only really applies to 27 of you. Just as a reminder, you can always check to see if you've filled out your survey correctly by looking at the main page of this Kickstarter campaign; it's guaranteed to be faster than sending an email. :-)
And now, for the apology part. Due to forces outside of our control, the additional Sentinels of the 9th promo cards that we announced in August will unfortunately be delayed. We won't be delaying the shipment of the game, however. That is still expected to be shipping out on schedule. Once we have the promo cards, we will be sending those out separately. Many apologies for that, folks.

Hey, everyone! I'm really happy to see everyone has been filling out their surveys. It's really been a great response. If you've already filled out your survey, you can pretty much ignore this update. If you have address changes or weird shipping things, you can skip to the last paragraph.
For you 37 backers that still haven't responded, however, we really need to get those in. In about 48 hours, we're going to start getting all of our ducks in a row for fulfilling this project. Part of that is printing over 2000 shipping labels, which takes a little time.

Hey everyone. We just sent out the backer surveys, so they should be arriving in your inbox any minute.
It is super important that these get filled out ASAP, especially for international orders. Delays in getting your address past the main shipment will mean a delay in your getting your game, and we definitely don't want to do that.
Bottom of the 9th is sailing the sea right now, and we should be getting things out to you  by the end of October!

updates.update_userinfo: Bottom of the 9th has left the factory!
updates.update_content:
This is some really great news. Bottom of the 9th has left the factory and is on its way to St. Louis! It won't be long now until we get to play ball.
What does this make the timing look like, you may ask? Well, if we have amazing luck, it will arrive here in late-ish October, just in time to get to many of you during the World Series. If we have average luck, it will get to you right after the World Series, just in time to stave off your baseball withdrawal symptoms.

By the way, I've found a way to play the game solo that is SUPER EASY. Basically, everything about the game stays the same except for a slight change to "The Stare Down." In that phase, you set the pitch (i.e. low and away) in the normal manner. Then you take the counters for the batter, cup them in your hands, and roll them like dice to get a random outcome. Play then continues as normal. Essentially, this means you are playing the pitcher's side of the game - setting the pitch purposefully without knowing where the batter will swing. But that makes sense since the pitcher has strategy factors in "The Stare Down" (fatigue and an ace pitch) where the batter does not. I've also found the decision-making that follows in "The Pitch" and "The Swing" to be pretty straight forward. Whether the pitcher or batter should +1, -1, roll again, etc. is fairly obvious within the game (that is NOT a complaint), no matter who you are rooting for to win. So it is not difficult to be honest in how you play even thought you are controlling both sides. I've played the game this way twice, and it was a lot of fun (pitcher won the first inning, batter won the second inning). Download the game and give it a try. Let me know if I missed anything.

When contact is made, both players roll once, applying any Fielding or Speed bonuses, and compare the result. A roll of a 5 or 6 is a success, meaning either the lead runner has been thrown out, or the hitter has reached first and everyone on base advanced. If neither player succeeds, they roll again. If both players succeed on the same roll, a higher roll would win out. If there is a tie, the runner(s) are safe.

@DHMG @Jim @Scott ... Thanks for your thoughts. On a perhaps somewhat related note, from anyone with hands-on experience, can it be said that it's set up to be basically a 50-50 game? That selecting the batter or the pitcher gives about the same chances of winning? Or is there not enough gameplay data yet? Just curious.

I also consider myself a "true" baseball fan, for whatever that's worth, but I think that's WAY overthinking this game. It's not a full simulator like Strat-O-Matic or Statis Pro. It's a 15 minutes or less filler game with enough baseball flavor to be thematically fun but doesn't take itself completely serious, hence the Sentinels booster cards. House rules it all you need to to make it enjoyable for you.

That being said, DHMG I believe have already said that there will be a variant where you can play a full 9-inning game if you want. Likewise, I've already imagined myself house-ruling it to go onto the 10th if it's a tie, switching roles and seeing how it all plays out. So it's always an option to just play multiple games and keep track of the score.

Wouldn't it make more sense to say: 1) Pitcher records three outs = WIN, 2) Pitcher allows only one run but records three outs = TIE (or continue playing, switching pitching and batting sides as necessary), 3) Batter scores two+ runs = WIN...? Or do you consider this just something game players would set up naturally as a home variant?

@Eric - Well what we are doing, for building your line-up is you are limited to 1 player per position (i.e. you can't have 2 first basemen within your line-up). So the normal game is played with 6 players and the full 9-inning variant is played with 8 players (using 1 per position, minus pitcher).

Kirk, we have but felt it was a bit too heavy. We have a different and cleaner way to draft- it also ensures you can't build a team of 100% power. :) We may implement a salary cap down the line- but it would be hard to code it into the current cards without a set strategy in place right now.

@Jason I've been cordial. You have not. I'd like you be respectful in your tone please. I'm happy to be apart of this project. I'm a fan of the DHMG podcast, and their gaming preferences. I think this game looks fantastic. If I didn't, I wouldn't have been up that early on a Monday before a 10 hour manual labor shift to secure such an exclusive item and upgraded player field. If you don't like my argument that's fine, I've made my point. But the fact still remains that I HAVE an argument.

@Jesse It's the job of the makers of the games to make a good product, not make sure that you can resell it on BGG. For every backer like you there are 20 backers like me who don't care and just want to play this awesome game. That's why they don't care if you just drop your pledge and go away; you are more trouble than you're worth.

I didn't make the card exclusive. I didn't set the parameters of the pledge levels. I didn't broadcast the fact that the card would be limited to 50 pledges. That was Dice Hate Me Games. It's their project, they can do what they want. But it sets a precedent that I'm not a fan of. And being my first DHMG project that I've backed, it doesn't bode well for future projects, as far as I'm concerned. I back a lot of projects, and spend a lot of money on KS. Project managers shouldn't want to alienate backers like me.
At least there's word play!

@Jesse, you sound like a disappointed eBay seller upset that his prospect for selling this rare card on eBay has just dried up. If you are buying the game to play it, this move doesn't affect your enjoyment of the game at all.
@Kierkegaard555 I'm not hostile, just disappointed. And the 50 All-Star pledges were gone in less than 30mins of the project launching, not 48 hours.

I had to deal with the KS server issues the same as everyone else. I had 3 tabs open, all trying to secure a spot in sequence. As one failed due to server load, I started the next, and so on. I took me a good 20 minutes. So when I say "know the difference between an argument, and complaining", I mean it. No one who secured an All-Star pledge had any advantage other than a greater sense of perseverance. campaign.story:
Foam Brain Games is excited to be back with our first ever licensed jewelry and pin collection for one of our favorite games - Sentinels of the Multiverse. In collaboration with the awesome folks at Greater Than Games, we've produced a selection of awesome Sentinels of the Multiverse tee shirts, pins, rings and more!
Everything in this collection is scheduled to ship in early December of this year - just in time to make great Christmas gifts!
STRETCH GOAL #2 ACHIEVED - EVERY PLEDGE OF $30 OR MORE WILL GET A FREE SENTINELS OF THE MULTIVERSE LOGO PIN!
Single pins for $6 each or a complete set for $70
Our Sentinels collection features 14 pins from the Sentinels universe. Below are the original logos which will be turned into stunning metal and enamel pins:
 Hats for $22 each (adjustable)
Stretch Goal #1 Complete! We will be offering a replica of Mr. Fixer's hat from Rook City, embroidered onto an adjustable (via metal d-ring slider) cloth hat.
Earrings for $9 per pair
Silver stud earrings are nickel-free!
All of the earrings in this collection are stud earrings measuring approximately 17mm across. Each of the super hero symbols shown below will be available in silver, gold, and antique brass colors.
Cufflinks for $18 per pair
Each pair of high quality cufflinks comes in your choice of color - silver, gold, or antique brass.
Tie Clips for $12 each
This collection features a Sentinels Comics tie clip, in silver, gold, or antique brass colors.

The Legacy Ring for $25 each
Silver colored - comes on an 18" chain, intended to be worn as a necklace. Also available in an heirloom edition (see below for more information)
Unisex Tee Shirts for $20 each (Youth S to XL and Adult S to 5XL - add $3 for 2XL or 3XL or $5 for 4XL or 5XL)
Women's Fitted Tees for $24 each (S to 3XL - add $3 for 2XL or 3XL)
 (Note - these are all digitally generated samples, actual tee shirts will be silkscreened onto high quality name brand shirts)
With great excitement, we would like to announce the first piece of the Foam Brain Gear Heirloom Collection. This collection is going to feature extraordinarily limited edition precious metal jewelry made in the US. 
Heirloom Collection Legacy Ring - $699
The first piece in this collection is The Legacy Ring, rendered in genuine sterling silver. It comes in a mahogany presentation box, with the Foam Brain Gear and Sentinels of the Multiverse logos laser-engraved on it, plus personal text if desired. It comes with a hologram-numbered certificate of authenticity.

This is a limited edition - only 15 rings will ever be made.
The ring is an exact replica of the ring from the game, right down to the inscription inside - "FURTHERING YOUR FATHER'S LEGACY"
Sizes: Available in your choice of size from 5-17
Material: Solid Sterling Silver
Limited edition: only 15 will ever be made!
You can add on any additional items from this project as part of the same pledge. Just make sure that your total pledge includes the cost of all items you'd like.
Foam Brain Games is committed to making our projects accessible to retailers. If you're a retailer and would like more information, please drop us a line via Kickstarter PM.
The Foam Brain Gear: Sentinels of the Multiverse Collection is produced by Foam Brain Games under license from Greater Than Games.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is our seventh kickstarter campaign. We've delivered our previous projects close to on time and with fantastic results. We have a reputation for prompt customer service and this has only gotten better with the introduction of our new online sales and shipping department.

Currently we have 2 projects waiting to deliver, both well on schedule to their mid-September and October delivery dates.

This is our first clothing project, but we are using the same screen printers we've used for staff shirts for years.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: Announcing the Foam Brain Gear: Sentinels of the Multiverse 2015 Collection!
Foam Brain Gear: Sentinels of the Multiverse 2015 Collection Coming Tomorrow!
updates.update_content:
Hi everyone! A few weeks ago I mentioned we'd be launching this year's Sentinels collection in the near future and I wanted to take a moment to give everyone a preview of the Sentinels of the  Multiverse 2015 collection we'll be launching here on Kickstarter tomorrow at 1pm Eastern. You can check out the preview at:
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1006691271/1572952613?token=54bc9e3d
We're using a fantastic new silk screener and I think the Adam and the Sentinels team has gone above and beyond with the amazing new designs they've made for us for this campaign.

updates.update_userinfo: Rings, Flasks, Shirts, Upcoming Products and more!
updates.update_content:
Hi everyone! I hope things are going well. There's a lot going on in this email, so please take a read through it all.
Legacy Rings
First of all - some bad news :( Over the weekend we got back the fourth factory attempt on the rings and we're still not happy with the quality. The rings look perfect, but the text looks awful (it fades badly and is fairly illegible.). I've talked with the folks at Greater than Games, and I think we agree the factory is not going to be able to deliver on the product it agreed to.

updates.update_userinfo: Announcing the Foam Brain Gear: King of Tokyo and King of New York Shirt Collection

updates.update_content:
Hi everyone! I hope you are all well. Once or twice a year, we put out a survey to find out what awesome things people would like us to look into producing in the future. We would appreciate it if you'd check it out: https://www.surveymonkey.com/s/fbapril2015. We'll be raffling off 2 Foam Brain Gift Packs to people who fill it out.
Thanks, and thanks as always for backing!
Andrew

Hi folks! I was hoping to be posting here with exciting news, but instead I have some bad news.
The good news is the factory figured out how to do the rings correctly and had included them in our pin order which came in today. The bad news is that there's a typo on them :( (it says Furthering your Father's Lega", so we'll be redoing them again. I'm sincerely sorry about the delay, but at least I know we'll have an awesome keepsake for you all when we get them right :)

Hi everyone! I hope things are going well. I just wanted to quickly let people know where things are with the Legacy rings.
The factory we used made a new test mold, but we didn't think it looked good enough - we're finding that having an engraving on the inside of a cast object is much more challenging than I had expected, but we're going to create a new mold as soon as CNY is over and try again (we may end up having to cast them, enscribe them and then coat them instead which is a lot more time\labor\money intensive but is a possible solution).

Hey folks! I hope people are doing well. I forgot to mention this last week but we'd love to see some photos of people wearing Sentinels merch! Please tag us on twitter @foambrain or Facebook @foambrain, especially if you're willing to let us post them as action shots on our website.
Also, as a reminder our Metal Dice campaign ends on Tuesday at Noon Eastern. We've added a bunch of cool stuff, including Japanese dice, free spotted D6s and dice rolling mats. You can check it out here: http://kck.st/1ABekBU

Hi folks - I hope things are going well :) I just wanted to stop in with a few brief updates:
1) It's been a few weeks since we've shipped stuff, so if you're a US backer and haven't received your order, take a moment and drop us a line so we can look into it. If you're an international backer, give it another few weeks and then drop us a line. We want to do everything we can to ensure everyone receives their product :)
2) I'm excited to announce Foam Brain's newest kickstarter, Foam Brain Dice: Metals 2. This project is allowing us to revisit the very first thing we made and make more of it, adding new colors and styles, plus enhancing the dice bags we ship things in. I'm very excited about it, and I hope you will all check it out.

Hey folks! I just got off the phone with our screen printer and I spoke to our metals manufacturer last night, so I wanted to take a moment to update everyone on where things stand.
Basically, everything is going to be showing up Mon-Wed of next week at our store, and we'll be shipping them out on Thurs and Fri. I'll make sure we post some pictures as things show up. For US backers, the USPS says this means you should get your products in time for Christmas. For international backers, you should get them shortly therafter.

campaign.story:
ABOUT THIS PROJECT
Community is important. We believe that there are a great number of Gay, Lesbian, Transgender, Gender Queer, and Bisexual folks out there, of every color and creed, that at the end of the day, love to geek out. Geek about video games, tabletop games, tech, comics - all that fun stuff. And we believe that creating a community for these folks, Gaymers as they are affectionally dubbed, is important to help shape a more tolerant and safer space in gaming. After all, everyone games.
The stereotypes about gamers are many, but the core is the perception that gamers are usually straight white guys in dark rooms furiously mashing at a controller. That’s not the reality. Gamers come in all sizes, genders, races, and sexual identities. Unfortunately stereotypical bias among gamers does exist and it can make a hostile environment for minorities in the gaming community. Hang around an online game long enough and you’ll start hearing homophobic, racial, and misogynistic slurs slung around without a second thought. Gamers, as a whole, have had to make space for themselves in a society that, for a long time, treated them as outsiders. They have come together and created a real community of people, but one that is not always welcoming if you don’t fit into the mold. Just like most gamers, queer geeks and gaymers want that same sense of community and belonging. Therefore we intend to create a space where all gamers and queer geeks can come together in a welcoming and safe space.
This space is GaymerCon.
We are creating a convention where all types of geeks can come together, meet others like them, and have a blast without having to worry about what their peers think of them or being discriminated against.. We will have exhibitor space, cosplay, guest speakers, live music, panel discussions on topics that are directly relevant to our interests, gaming industry professionals who support including queer content in their products, social events, and of course…GAMING!
We will also have events and activities that target other areas of geek and tech culture besides gaming. From tabletop gaming to geek chic, from panels by tech leaders to cosplay and live music- we hope to have something for everyone.
We want to be clear this isn’t just for gay white dudes either. We want all genders, races, and sexual identities including our straight friends and allies to come together and have a gay, geeky good time. We believe very strongly that creating a space like this is not only important for building a strong community, but also showing new generations of gaymers that there are others like them out there, they are not alone, and there is a welcoming place for them, not just at GaymerCon, but as part of the larger gaming community. 
WHAT THE MONEY IS FOR
GaymerCon is going to happen no matter what in the late summer of 2013, but big events like this don’t happen by magic and certainly aren’t cheap. This is where you come in. Without any donations we will create a great space for gaymers to come together, build community, and have fun. WITH your donations however, we can reserve swankier and more centrally located venues, book more geeky bands to play for you, have more consoles and games to play on, have cool prizes for contests, and more. Basically the more you give, the more you get out of the con when you come. If we raise lots and lots of money, it will get the attention of the gaming industry, making them more likely to come to the show too so you can see their awesome stuff, but also let them know there is a market out there for gaymers and maybe they should pay attention to you. All this for what it costs for a day pass to most other conventions....oh and did we mention that almost all pledges come with a free pass to the con? Yup. That’s a thing. Go ahead and go donate. We’ll wait.
Can't come to GaymerCon? We also have sticker packs and Blue/Red GaymerCon Bitroms, for those supporters who want a little more Gaymer in their lives.
Bitroms are entirely original hand-made cartridge necklaces - choose from either Fire Red Conway, Cool Blue Turing, or (at higher levels) you can get the limited Kickstarter-edition Turing & Conway's Adventure.
HOW DO YOU KNOW WE WON’T JUST SPEND THE MONEY ON MOUNTAIN DEW AND CHEETOS
We know we can make Gaymercon a success because we are already experienced in being successful. We have a team of extremely talented, connected, amazing folks on the team including engineers and business folks at top startups here in San Francisco. These include Jack DeVries out of IGN, Zach Weiner from SMBC Comics which is one of the largest comics and websites in the world and Matt Conn from the founding team of BandPage, as well as other visionaries and leaders from the LBGT & fundraising world.
Also: Cheetos and Mountain Dew? Ew.
Please consider contributing and we hope to see you in August 2013.
Wait...you’re still not convinced? Alright. Fine. Time to bring out the big guns. What if I told you that a certain evil computer from a certain video game that starts with a “P” and ends with an “ortal” thought you should? You really going to say no to her?
See you at GaymerCon 2013!
Tweet at us at @GaymerCon or follow us at facebook.com/gaymercon to stay up to date. We won't camp at your spawn point. Promise.
FAQ
Who are you?
We are a bunch of geeks and allies based mostly around the Bay and Seattle areas. Most of us work in the tech or gaming space.

Why isn't there a venue set?
That's one of the main reasons why we're holding this Kickstarter - depending on demand and the amount raised, we'll be able to find a location that fits the expected attendance. The more we raise, the more awesome the space we can get, and hopefully get some awesome panels and bosses of honor, too!

Why is it in San Francisco? Why isn't it in ______?
San Francisco is where the highest concentration of gaming, geekdom, tech, and gay communities all coincide, and for year one, we want to make sure it is in an area where there is already, what we hope, is strong demand.
Who are Conway and Turing?
Conway and Turing are based off of two LGBT geek heroes that we wish to honor as well as help educate the young folks on:  Alan Turing, with whom we would not all the amazing technology and toys that we have to today, and Lynn Conway, engineering pioneer and activist for the transgender community.

I'm under 18 - Can I go?
For at least the first year, GaymerCon will be an 18+ event. Although we understand that helping create a safe space for youth is just as important to our mission, for year one, there are a lot of insurance and liability issues to take into account with minors. If you'd still like to come, please let us know so we can gauge demand!
I'm Straight! Can I come? 
Of course! We want to create a gaming and tech event that focuses on queer issues and themes, not the other way around. Similar to Gay & Lesbian film festivals and cultural events, we welcome all and hope to provide a fun, exciting, vibrant community that is in no way closed off from the rest of the gaming community.
I don't think something is a good idea becuase of [valid reason]/I would like to see [something cool]
We are always down to discuss and help explain our point of view and also listen to, and learn, from others. We are forging new ground with GaymerCon and a helping build a new community - and we want to hear what you think. Please drop us a line on fb or @gaymercon
I would like to troll you because... 
Be nice, please. We're trying to create something that we believe can help make the lives of gay geeks around the world a bit more interesting and more social. We can take the heat, but we'd prefer if you could please keep it civil.
Wait, I'll only sponsor this if I can get in the field reccomendations from my peers set to Japanese chiptune music.
Got it.
NEW! 
STRETCH GOALS!!
35K - GAYMERCONCERT! (UPDATE: WE DID IT!!!) GaymerCon will hold a GaymerConcert on Saturday night, bringing in musicians and bands that appeal greatly to the Gaymer community, for a night of drinking, dancing and socializing! Chiptune slow dance, anyone?
50K - GAYMER BRUNCHFAST FOR THOSE PLEDGING $100+! (UPDATE: WE DID THIS TOO!!!!) Many of you have said that you wish you could have lunch with us on Sunday, but we wanted to make sure that that was special to those who donated at that level. However, we really want to meet with everyone one of you, soooo... if we hit $50K, everyone who has donated $100 or more will be invited to have free breakfast with us the Sunday morning of the con. This will be a bigger group, but we'll still try to make our way around to thank each one of you in person. It will be our honor to do so. If you've already pledged below $100 and want to join...just up it to $100 and you're in.
60K- CELEBRITY BOSS OF HONOR: (UPDATE: SUPER FINAL BOSS MODE UNLOCKED!) GaymerCon will bring in a real awesome celebrity to be an official BOSS OF HONOR. Think of all the gay, lesbian, trans, and allied geek celebrities out there - who would YOU like to see?
100K: GAYMERCONNECT: We want to build an app - web first, then mobile, called GaymerConnect. The idea? That you can easily go in and find other Gaymers to play your favorite games with. Playing Call of Duty? Here are all the Queer Clans. Looking for someone to fight against in Street Fighter 4? Here are 20 awesome geeks to play against.
The best (and most relevant) part: we can coordinate GaymerConnect with GaymerCon itself, setting up an easy and instant way for you to connect online with all the awesome people you meet at the con.

updates.update_content:
Hello Backers,
Since the split of the GaymerX and MidBoss companies, we realized we needed to determine the fate of the Kickstarter account as well. We have decided that this account will officially become the MidBoss one and any outstanding concerns will be our responsibility (though all previous campaigns be good to go by now). The original account was created by Matt Conn for GaymerCon (now GaymerX). Since he is no longer is a part of the company, he has delegated control of the account to new MidBoss head, Cade Peterson, to ensure any future use of the account is set up and proper.

Hey backers! It’s Giving Tuesday!!! Are you familiar with it? It’s like Black Friday or Cyber Monday, but instead of being focused on mark-downs its about donating to your favorite organizations. We thought this would be a great time to let you know that last week we relaunched our Patreon!! 
 Y’all especially know how important crowd-funding is to us. Everything we’ve been able to do has been thanks to the support of all of you. GaymerX never could have existed without Kickstarter, and that’s help us grow into Midboss, which brought about Gaming in Color and . So we wanted to make sure you all knew that we’re trying something new!

campaign.story:
UPDATE!
First, we reached our initial funding goal in less than 24 hours! Next, we achieved our first set of stretch goals in under 1 week! Now we have met our second set of expanded goals in just 2 weeks!
Read Update #4: OMG! 1000 backers! (and about that harassment stuff)
About this Project:
I love playing video games but I’m regularly disappointed in the limited and limiting ways women are represented.  This video project will explore, analyze and deconstruct some of the most common tropes and stereotypes of female characters in games.  The series will highlight the larger recurring patterns and conventions used within the gaming industry rather than just focusing on the worst offenders.  I’m going to need your help to make it happen!
As a gamer, a pop culture critic and a fan, I’m always working to balance my enjoyment of media while simultaneously being critical of problematic gender representations. With my video web series Feminist Frequency,  I look at the way women are portrayed in mass media and the impact they have on our culture and society.
THE PROJECT
With your help, I’ll produce a 5-video series (now expanded to 12 videos) entitled Tropes vs Women in Video Games, exploring female character stereotypes throughout the history of the gaming industry.  This ambitious project will primarily focus on these reoccurring tropes: 
Damsel in Distress - Video #1
The Fighting F#@k Toy - Video #2
The Sexy Sidekick - Video #3
The Sexy Villainess - Video #4
Background Decoration - Video #5
1st Set of Stretch Goals Achieved!
Voodoo Priestess/Tribal Sorceress - Video #6
Women as Reward - Video #7
Mrs. Male Character - Video #8
Unattractive Equals Evil - Video #9
Man with Boobs - Video #10
Positive Female Characters! - Video #11
2nd Stretch Goal Achieved! 
Let's Bump up the Production Quality!
3rd Set of Stretch Goals Achieved!
Tropes vs Women in Video Games Classroom Curriculum 
Video #12 - Top 10 Most Common Defenses of Sexism in Games
Each video will be between 10 and 20 minutes long and available online for free for everyone and anyone to watch, share and use.
Creating these videos take a lot of time and money to produce. I will be researching and playing hundreds of titles from across the gaming industry (including some truly awful games that I wouldn’t wish upon anyone!). Your support will go towards production costs, equipment, games and downloadable content.
Please pledge any amount you can and become a backer of Feminist Frequency’s Tropes vs Women in Video Games!
Feminist Frequency is an ongoing web series of video commentaries focusing on representations of gender, race, class, sexuality and ability in pop culture. 
Last year I released a video series called Tropes vs Women analyzing female representations in the mainstream media.  This previous series was highly successful and shared all over the web.  Not only did it provide people the language to understand the media they were engaging with, but it's even served as a guide for some professional writers and media creators to actively avoid gendered character stereotypes and create more in-depth, and more engaging female characters.  
Help me create another successful video series that will contribute to and help amplify the existing conversations happening about female characters in games and maybe even get the attention of the gaming industry to start creating more interesting, engaging and complex female characters, that avoid the standard boring cliches.
Visit FeministFrequency.com to see examples of my previous video work.
Kickstarter doesn't have subtitle integration with their videos so I've posted a full transcript of the video here.

updates.update_content:
Hi everyone!
We are thrilled to announce that an outstanding curriculum supporting the Tropes vs. Women in Video Games series is now available! Designed by education experts for use in the classroom, in community organizations, and anywhere that educators or viewers may wish to get the most out of the Tropes series, the curriculum features lessons crafted specifically around every individual episode of Tropes. These robust lesson plans offer educators a rich, flexible assortment of activities, discussion topics and related resources to aid viewers in making connections between the information presented in the videos themselves and the ways in which women are viewed and treated in our culture at large.

10. none of these ideas call for a radical alteration of gaming culture or design. They don't call for 'do-goodism' to spoil the entertainment of gaming. But just as comic books and other popular media don't leave their heroes and heroines unscathed by injuries and changing times, video games shouldn't either. It's not about political correctness, it's about creating a gaming atmosphere in which all people from all cultures can take part.

I don't think anyone wants to put an end to 'save the princess' style games. But as many of you have seen in movies like Star Wars, Aliens, and others, princesses can also save themselves, or save other princesses, or they can save princes, or they can lead armies and not need to be saved at all. Saving the princess isn't evil. What's disturbing is when the princess has no personality, and when there's no compelling reason to save her except that she's a McGuffin, and when she seems incapable of trying to escape or fight back on her own. Ms. Pac-Man refuses to go down without a fight, but Princess Peach just sits there. If you were a father or mother, which game would you choose for your son or daughter? Which message is important to you? If you can say GTA is 'just a video game', why aren't there male hookers like those that exist in real cities? There are real mostly female drug gang crews in the real world; why not show them in video games? If men in video games can be ugly and not sexy, or old, or smart, why can't women be shown that way, and why does 'sexy' have to mean a short skirt and a big rack, when real world sexy women come in many forms?

@Melanie re Republique: This game certainly does fit the damsel in distress trope so it may not make many friends here on that front. However, one of the stated aims is to make a non-sexualised female lead - and they mention specifically that this is to the point that they would meet resistance from traditional publishers in this ambition. Also, they want to realize the main character 'Hope' and the (platonic) player relationship with her in quite a bit of depth (your character in this game is yourself, whatever gender you are). Lastly, having read about the game in depth, I believe the small amount of footage in the previews is misleading regarding how much Hope will depend on the player. All up, I am personally looking forward to this very different game, and also hold hope that it may treat women well and be enjoyable to play for women too.

@Melanie: I hadn't read those comments of Ron Rosenberg's. They are quite unfortunate - I don't understand how he can describe it as 'you helping her' when you are playing AS her :( I agree with you, I sure hope that guy's perspective is not what the dev team is going for. Maybe he just can't deal with playing a game AS a female character!

By the way, the idea of female protagonists as someone to help and protect would be an interesting trope to investigate. Beyond: Two Souls (playing as Aiden) and Republique (also recently funded through Kickstarter) are two games where it is more explicit in the gameplay than in TR, although none of these games are out yet. Not sure if there are other games that do this, or if it's a new trend created by developers trying to make more female leads, but not quite willing to let them stand completely on their own yet. This might fit in with the Damsels in Distress, but I think it deserves to be mentioned as a particular variant since it seems to be turning into kind of a thing.

@Arlene and Pamela: The new Tomb Raider game might actually be quite a good game for gender equality. It's not 'young Lara is almost raped; becomes strong'. Rather, as a young woman with no special survival skills she is on a cruise ship that sinks and she washes up on a lawless wild island. She then overcomes many trials including the wild animals, potential starvation and also some modern day pirates/smugglers. There is a scene where these men intend her harm, but it's not necessarily rape - could just be regular old murder. In either case, it will be a game in which the player IS the damsel in distress (rather than her shining knight) and through sheer determination she saves herself and becomes a force to be reckoned with. I don't know if the final game will turn out quite like that, but if it does, it seems like that would be a good step for women in games to me?

@Kristina Brun Madsen, I agree about the game development thing. Not only is it expensive, but when anyone tries to make something to be "the positive example" of doing the right thing, rather than working from a real spark of inspiration, the results are almost always second-rate and come off like a PSA. And it's not like you can address all the issues of a variety of representations and themes in one game, anyway! There's also the simple fact that providing ONE good game in a sea of bad ones doesn't actually address the pervasive cultural forces at work in the bad games, and doesn't promote media literacy as far as helping people to realize what is bad in the existing games and how that should inform their purchases and participation in that culture. Moreover, not everyone who cares about this project is a gamer, just like how not everyone who cares about the pinkification of Legos has kids or plays with Legos--but I love sociology, and I love to learn about my culture and others, and subcultures within them, and to consider how the choices I and others make contribute to various social norms and the effects on people's lives.

The first thing to do is to understand the nature of the project. Since this series will be in the format of her previous series (Tropes vs. Women), that's a good series to check out a video from to get an example of what to expect. Basically, the format introduces what a trope is; why it's harmful; examples of the trope in numerous sources; an explanation of how to avoid the harmful parts of the trope, suggestion for improvement, and some positive examples of characters that are not defined by the trope, but could be. The problem isn't that there are sexy women in video games, but that those sexy women are the only women, and that they are frequently NOT presented as whole, complete, capable people who have lives of their own. There need to be women of all types and men of all types for a video game to be truly rich and complex. There's a wider variety of types of male characters available in video games right now, though, and most of their tropes are of a more positive nature than the ladies, so Anita's just going to be looking at the tropes that affect ladies to try to explore ways to better represent them. I imagine the advice she provides would be helpful for characters of any gender!

@alien07, I think you should check out Anita's videos when she's all done making them. At present, this kickstarter campaign is a proposal to dig in and do some research and then to provide some educational videos that present the results of her analysis. I think you'll get better answers to your questions with the finished product, instead of looking for them in her proposal.

I had a friend who also was concerned about this. Have you given Anita's previous series (Tropes vs. Women) a bit of a look? This is more the kind of approach I think you can expect-- deconstruction of what is harmful about a stereotype, then what is not actually bad about it, examples of that stereotype across the years in various sources, and examples of HOW the stereotype is harmful. She then provides some positive examples of characters that fit that bill, and suggestions on how to improve representations of characters in the future. (Hopefully that helps!)

I must admit, at the moment I struggle with the definition of and negativity about 'tropes'. It seems to me that no matter how interesting and deep a fictional character is, in order to discuss tropes, the character will need to be described in a short sentence, thus stripping them of all uniqueness and texture. Once this step has been done, it is hardly surprising that many characters are 'the same', thus: time for a new trope. Or is the problem being discussed here that the actual tropes for females in games are not a great selection to choose from? (but the existence of tropes in general is not in itself an issue?).

@David- Well, the trope is enough to put me off it anyway. She's...a damsel. In distress. Who "you", Big *Brother*, save. She isn't the protagonist- Big *Brother* (you) are, and "you" are a dude (the player is specifically named as Brother in the game description, regardless of the player's actual gender), saving a damsel, who is in distress. She specifically does not solve puzzles- Big *Brother* does this. Otherwise you'd just watch the game instead of playing it, and she wouldn't whimper and beg for help through the whole demo, she'd just get it done. This game tries to appeal to the fantasy of playing a strong male protector, helping the weak, terrified, trapped (pretty, young) woman. It doesn't give me confidence either that Wikipedia says "The idea for Hope came about when [Peyton] was performing a thought experiment about how to make Love Plus for a Western audience." Though she doesn't have to be a prize, just somebody the tough, manly dude can rescue. (A woman who's the prize at the end is Woman as Prize. Most of the time you don't have to choose just one.)

@AdrianH They're releasing Republique for PC, and I must be atypical since the more innovative the game mechanics, the more interested I am. Speaking of which, the only reason I'm not already backing 'Clang' is the steep hardware cost to play it properly...

@Kristian: I wonder about this too. The team making Republique have big ideas for the game and the protagonist - they discuss this a lot in interviews - they definitely want to make her a well-realized, interesting, non-sexualised character, not a simple trope. However, we certainly don't see that yet, the preview videos so far only show a pretty typical "damsel in distress" trope. I guess we will see as they progress further into designing the game.

@David To be fair, there's nothing particularly "active" about the female protagonist in Republique. She runs around scared all the time and needs the player's help to deal with most enemies and obstacles etc. It's a neat gameplay idea alright, but fits depressingly well within the classic "damsel in distress" trope which will be discussed in the webseries.
The drive was going to hit the $26,000 stretch goal before she posted her video on YouTube. But since then, her numbers have been incredible.
Go get em, Anita

@David: I'm excited about Republique too and wish it had done better. But I think you have to remember that the reasons why games get backed for how much is very complex - whether the protagonist is male or female probably doesn't even make the top 10 factors! Much more important factors are what platform(s) the game is for (PC good, iOS bad), if it appeals to nostalgia (more money if it does), and if it's trying anything new (trying something new being generally bad for getting funded).

Even after those complaints I would think that Diablo III is still a commendable effort at being gender inclusive, and certainly better than most games around. The option to play as a female or male in every player class is (like I previously mentioned) an incredibly expensive exercise that Blizzard chose to do, presumably for the specific purpose of being gender equal.

I would love to see interviews with developers that have created some of the positive female characters. But I think trying help developers make better female characters might also be a good goal. I'm not sure how that would work, because a lot of people seem resistant to the idea that there's any problem with games.

I'm a graduate student in a university in Texas. This last semester, I was one of two men who decided to take a feminism course towards an English credit. The course was amazing, and charted feminism through the waves of thought throughout history. For my cumulative research essay, I wrote a paper on how I thought women were being objectified in video games, and how some characters are attempting to evolve past their common stereotypes. My paper focused on Lara Croft, who was created to literally be "the adolescent male fantasy". I charted her evolution through time, and how she evolved into more of a character than a common ideal. Her dominance in the Guardian of Light game despite her being paired with a male counterpart was really fun to deconstruct. In two weeks, I'm going to have a niece, and I don't want her growing up expecting her future to be something akin to waiting for a masculine character to come to her "rescue". That's why I plan to teach her the difference between reality and gender portrayals.

Here's another article that takes a fuller perspective on the debate surrounding Bayonetta. As I said, I recognize that the fact that she has been created by males with a male audience in mind is problematic. I have serious doubt that the creators had any thought of feminism when they created her. Yet I have trouble arguing against the end result.

@Patrik, I think there's a difference between actually being strong and just being feisty. Just acting in a self-assured way does not actually make what one is doing "on one's own terms"--rather, it's the creation of a fictional character whose strongest motivations just so happen to be exactly that which pleases her male gaming audience...how convenient. Ultimately, Bayonetta just seems to be an embodiment of the same old male-pleasing tropes, but she just seems to really, really like that role--the apogee of internalized sexism. This is the sort of faux-empowerment that feminist discourse refers to as "empowerful."
http://web.archive.org/web/20100109032922/http://www.gamepro.com/article/features/213466/bayonetta-empowering-or-exploitative/

What I saw was complaints about her pornographic poses and getting naked to unleash her powerful attacks, which I can see some problems with, seeing how the target audience and creators are mainly males, but I still like how she turned out. As a strong, sexual woman who is never a victim. Everything sexual she does is on her terms, she doesn't have to please anyone else.

I'm not saying people will necessarily receive a character rewrite well, and that's a reasonable complaint in and of itself. It's just not necessarily sexist. Actually, when I saw stuff from the game was THAT close to how Uncharted has moved, I was more annoyed that the team was less trying to one-up Uncharted and more trying to copy it with Lara and not quite getting why it's working with Uncharted and not when you just plug Lara into Uncharted.

I think I see your point. Having only played one of the older Tomb Raider games back in the day, and none of the Uncharted series, I don't know much of the history we're discussing here. I do think that the complaints you're seeing are probably coming for three different reasons, despite the similarity you rightly point out between the two game series and why Tomb Raider might seek to emulate Uncharted. First: Players who stick with a game series even when it doesn't change are often fond of the formula as-is. I remember Tomb Raider being the kind of game where Lara was generally a wisecracking badass, more directly comparable to Indiana Jones than anyone else. Like Indiana Jones, she was completely in control, but it seemed that inevitably, one of her helpful contacts would betray her in the middle of the adventure, causing an annoying setback. If this formula may be lost in the new game, which seems to take on a more serious tone, the old fans who liked things as they were might be disappointed, feeling that something is being fixed that wasn't broken. Second: I've watched a youtube video showing the demo and the trailer, and in one spot of the demo when the guy grabs Lara's leg, she shrieks in rising terror and eventually kicks him off. I think the way in which this was portrayed may feel to many like the threat that Lara can get raped is being introduced at all, even though she gets herself out of the situation. So the complaint might just be that if it was Nathan, he wouldn't be wriggling and shrieking in the same way because he'd be portrayed as responding to the same assault differently. This could be the characters being different, but we're agreed that Lara Croft and Nathan of Uncharted are really similar in personality, so why should she act differently (frightened and shrieking) than he would in this situation? It's suspicious. Third: I also think people might be concerned since this is the first Tomb Raider game published since Eidos was acquired by Square-Enix (though there was a game lacking the name Tomb Raider according to the timeline I've found on Wikipedia). Square-Enix's handling of the character is bound to be a little different than previous games', and the creative team on the project may be totally different. That's a legitimate concern for the character being treated in a different way, and could lead people to worry about how it will turn out based on what little they've seen so far.
Please continue your great work. It's important not just to the female gaming community but to the pop culture community that undermines the image of women.

Anita! I have been a huge fan of your videos for a LONG time and I am so happy that despite all the trolls and haters on your youtube that you've gone beyond your goal by several thousand dollars. As a recent college grad I can only do $10 but I'm happy to support a sister in the struggle. Keep on keepin' on.
1$ pledge
Upping my pledge because of the lovely commenters on youtube.

I'd feel like Lara had failed if she had actually failed at something in the trailer. The worst thing that happens is a bear trap. Everything else she gets out of on her own, using her own skills. I watched the E3 demo and saw nothing that implied she was "failing" at anything either. I am literally comparing her to the most direct male counterpart to her series and seeing nothing in there that Drake hasn't been through.

@Rebecca: The problem isn't so much that women are being depicted in peril. It's that women are almost exclusively depicted in peril. Women are so commonly depicted as being inept, or not ept enough to handle their male competitors, in everything pop culture-- video games being just one good example-- that it doesn't hurt to have the occasional woman who doesn't get portrayed as failing all the time. As a women, don't you feel a little frustrated, a little bit of crushing hopelessness, if you have to watch your hero-- say, Lara Croft, or Wonder Woman, or Xena-- fail at a task that her male counterparts succeed at? It's got an effect on us all. We want to see women succeeding more often because currently, successful women are under-represented. (Just as non-sexualized women are under-represented.) I can't speak for everyone else, but that's the gist I've gotten from seeing the demo myself, and from the anger people have with regard to it.

Seriously, compare it to Uncharted 2 - how does that game open, with Nathan kicking ass and taking names...or bleeding out and nearly dying of frostbite? The entire game has him taking wound after wound and failing at task after task. I think people suggesting that he somehow has a super happy fun time that Lara is being deprived of need to actually play the games.
Both trailers are highly problematic.

I won't claim to have played every video game ever, but I rarely see the topic of sexual violence actually addressed, let alone shown in a negative light. I think it's a necessary topic to broach considering the problems we still have with gaming and how it views women. If gamers actually saw rape for what it is, they might stop using it as a casual insult in multiplayer matches.

But why have sexualized violence at all? Because Lara's a woman and women get raped? That's an awful justification for something happening to a character. Replace Lara with a guy and the sexualized violence wouldn't be there. Just look at Uncharted, is Nathan Drake ever threatened like Lara is in that trailer? None of the other Tomb Raider games have played the rape card, they haven't had to. If you want to show a character getting beat up while in a dangerous situation, fine, but this isn't that. This is a certain kind of violence that's being inflicted on Lara because she's a woman. It's being done for shock value but it's not only sexist it's lazy writing, as if you can't show a female character in a dangerous situation without her being threatened with rape. It's like in Arkham City where all the goons that Catwoman fights threaten to rape her (though nobody threatens to rape Batman).

If anything, it's the Hitman trailer in reverse. That trailer glamorizes and glorifies violence against a woman, right down to making the brutalized nuns have the sexiest deaths possible while minimizing the amount of actual brutality. It portrays the source of that violence as the victor. This one shows what violence against women actually is - horrifying and unpleasant. As it SHOULD be. And then it shows a woman keeping the power that her tormentors try to take from her.

It may just be the editing of the trailer (I really hope it is) but it looks like Lara's been put into one of those awful horror movies where the female character just wanders around and gets beaten up a lot while whispering variations on "oh my god". We see very little of Lara accomplishing anything at all. There's also the fact that all the violence is happening to women and women alone (crucified woman, Lara, Lara's kidnapped friend). And did they really have to make her interactions with the bad guys so rapey? I get it, women are in danger of being raped, but it just seemed so forced and a bit much on top of all the other shit that's going on in that trailer.
Someone explain to me why this one is equally as troubling as the Hitman trailer, because I'm afraid Lara is simply getting smacked with the "strong women cannot show fear" trope.
Bumping my pledge up after the Hitman and Tomb Raider trailers, as I hope a lot of people do now.
Upped to $50 after seeing what they've done to Lara Croft in the new Tomb Raider trailer. Funny how Nathan Drake can have adventures in exotic locales without being under constant sexual threat.
Glad I'm not the only one that's noticed the parallel between gaming and the American comic book industry.

So that is why I have more hope for casual + indie + mobile games. I like how smaller devs with new ideas can flourish in that environment without having to battle the status quo on the inside, and stigma on the outside.

I'd also love to see a developer pledge level that lets a studio or publisher etc. officially show their support of this effort. Especially if it came with the permission to use a badge saying that their organization explicitly supports feminist-friendly video games and/or gets their company name (rather than their personal name) in the credits. If you had something like this, we'd love to support this effort as a studio - I'm already pledged as an individual.
@Atarun Final Fantasy VI's main character was almost certainly Terra in the first half and Celes in the second half.

I'm psyched for this project. I believe that a lot of the stereotypes in video games deter female participation. I know I've seen it personally, as I date a casual female gamer. Good to see such a response, with the level of funding
Production quality BUMPED!! \o/

I used to be really into gaming. However, it seems that the industry and culture is only getting more misogynist and macho boy's club focused, not less. Thank you for this project. (And nice Peach and Zelda pictures!)
I'm with the folks who would like a T-shirt and/or poster, whether for TvW: WiVG or FemFreq in general.
Oh and I was refering to Balsa the protagonist in "Seirei no moribito".

I wonder too, maybe the second closest thing to females, homosexual in media (the closest should be transgender). Why do 99% of all gay men have to act like girls in movies and other media? Have a few friends who are gay and I certainly didn't know about it till they told me.

Is there a Seirei no Moribito video game?

@Atarun Then I suggest the anime "Seirei no moritobi" or "Guardian of the spirit" in english. Balsa (the protagonist) is way more heroic than Lightning, mainly because she's a middle-aged women and don't have a look of a skinny teenager and other things like her kickass spearstyle.
Those are my personal feelings about it. Not arguments.

Regarding FFX-2, I won't argue it's not an oddball. I actually enjoyed it because it was weird, but I also honestly like the more oddball entries and FFV is in my top 3 favorites games in the series. Just getting the job system back ensured I'd buy it day 1. But I also can't argue it's a bizarre tone switch from the incredibly serious and melancholy FFX. Yuna's outfit actually didn't bug me that much - it was an interesting reflection of her more ceremonial outfit in the previous title. Also, the shorts worked for the kind of stuff she was doing. It's Paine's outfit that makes me scratch my head (seriously, HOW DOES SHE PUT THAT ON!?). And I actually really liked Paine as a character.
@Rebecca Thank you. I was worried I was maybe bogging people down with walls of text.

In many ways Final Fantasy X-2 isn't as bad as some people made it out to be. It was basically just the return of the job system, and we can't be sure that made a return to be particularly girly in X-2. It also isn't that weird to see Rikku wearing a bathing top like that, considering that Spira is pretty much one gigantic, troubled beach resort. But Yuna... and those shorts... no. No no no. And a lot of the costumes were a bit, not so great. Others were pretty good, though. In general, it was kind of a medium title. It wasn't as bad as many probably made it out to be, but in general it was harder to take than its predecessor. And would have been, were it played differently. Final Fantasy X-2 is seen as more of a comedic diversion and fanservice to those who didn't want Final Fantasy X to end. And while that is okay, female characters deserve better than that. Final Fantasy over the years hasn't done much to do that. I would also say, yeah, that's the problem with Final Fantasy VI, Terra wasn't made clearly a female protagonist. The game immediately cuts into Locke and plenty of other characters and make them important and initiate situations. Which again, having a game about many characters is certainly fine. But a strong, female protagonist who can be taken seriously is deserved.

Finally, I'd point to Final Fantasy's rather large female following. I get a bit annoyed when people attack one of the few properties with a significant percentage of female players, because clearly they ARE providing something that makes women unafraid to play games. I also look at how many women my age cite characters like Terra or Tifa as heroes because they broke type. When you dismiss these characters, you also lose women who would otherwise be more approving of cleaning up the negative aspects of the industry.
I know, all of what I just said is subjective. Which is why I said I disagreed with you on the value of FF as a positive example and not that I thought you were wrong or something to that effect. ;)

http://web.archive.org/web/20100109032922/http://www.gamepro.com/article/features/213466/bayonetta-empowering-or-exploitative/

I love Bayonetta as well. I think she's an awesome character though I feel that she turned out that way almost inadvertently because she was designed, first and foremost, around her sex appeal. She works within her own game because the whole thing is pure camp and I hope the videos (if they do discuss her) take that context into consideration. However Bayonetta's the type of character that only really works once.
JoshuaH, don't worry about writing too much, that was a good piece :)
Gosh I write too much, sorry everyone. It'd be a little easier if you could at least make paragraph spacings. I tend to always have a lot on my mind. Again, sorry.
As I see it, both cultures have their own issues.

I wanted to highlight the fact that women consumers do exist and are a viable part of the market; especially given that the vast majority of games are already created according to what men want to see in them (whether that be sexist ideals or positive female representations). Yeah, a lot of men are definitely fed up with the sexism in games - I know pretty much all my friends are - but I think it's important to bring attention to the fact that /women/ are interested these issues and also have the power to bring about societal/cultural changes.

100% agreed. It's a strange dichotomy that Japanese games are far more likely to feature female leads, but they also tend to be more problematic leads. While Western games have no problem being as manly as possible. Like, I love Bayonetta, but I'm still of two minds because of the character's sexualization. I except she'll come up in the videos. On the one side, I tend to see Bayonetta as more sex-positive, but on the other, it's really sad that the idea of a female action hero required her to take her clothes off.

What's so weird is that most people don't seem to get that it's not just a "women want to play as women" thing. I've known tons of guys who would jump at the chance to play as a realistic non-sexualized female protagonist simply because it's something different.

@Gnosblax: Okay, I understand what you mean now, and in that respect, I actually agree with you. Though it kind of depends on your BioWare game as to how much the gender change matters outside of the romance subquests. Still, you're right that they're like the only one out there that's even trying. And I loved P3P and how they handled the female protagonist's storyline!
